text: Brigadier Lyndon Bolton DSO & Bar DL (1899 – 1995) was a British Olympic horseman. ==Biography== Born in London on 25 May 1899, Lyndon Bolton was educated at Bedford School, between 1906 and 1917, and at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich. He served in the British Army during the First World War, in 1918, and became a member of the British equestrian team in the 1930s. He served in France and North Africa with the Royal Horse Artillery during the Second World War, and was promoted to the rank of Brigadier in the 15th Scottish Division. He rode for Great Britain in the 1948 Summer Olympics, and finished 27th in the three-day event. He subsequently trained the Ireland Olympic equestrian team for the 1964 Summer Olympics.Obituary, The Northumberland Gazette, 12 April 1995 Brigadier Lyndon Bolton was invested as a Companion of the Distinguished Service Order in 1941, https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/35396/page/7333/data.pdf and again in 1945https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/37138/supplement/3227/data.pdf He died on 7 April 1995, aged 95. ==Publications== Thoughts on Riding, 1955, Training the Horse, 1964 ==References== Category:1899 births Category:1995 deaths Category:British male equestrians Category:People educated at Bedford School Category:Graduates of the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich Category:Olympic equestrians of Great Britain Category:Equestrians at the 1948 Summer Olympics Category:Companions of the Distinguished Service Order Category:British Army personnel of World War I Category:British Army personnel of World War II
